sn55.13:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ viharanti jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn55.13:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Sāriputta were staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn55.13:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn55.13:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn55.13:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.13:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him:

sn55.13:1.4.pli: “katinaṃ kho, āvuso ānanda, dhammānaṃ pahānā, katinaṃ dhammānaṃ samannāgamanahetu, evamayaṃ pajā bhagavatā byākatā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti?
sn55.13:1.4.eng: “Reverend, how many things do people have to give up and how many do they have to possess in order for the Buddha to declare that they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening?”

sn55.13:1.5.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, āvuso, dhammānaṃ pahānā, catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ samannāgamanahetu, evamayaṃ pajā bhagavatā byākatā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇāti.
sn55.13:1.5.eng: “Reverend, people have to give up four things and possess four things in order for the Buddha to declare that they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.13:2.2.pli: Yathārūpena kho, āvuso, buddhe appasādena samannāgato assutavā puthujjano kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa buddhe appasādo na hoti.
sn55.13:2.2.eng: They don’t have the distrust in the Buddha that causes an unlearned ordinary person to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn55.13:2.3.pli: Yathārūpena ca kho, āvuso, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato sutavā ariyasāvako kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa buddhe aveccappasādo hoti—
sn55.13:2.3.eng: And they do have the experiential confidence in the Buddha that causes a learned noble disciple to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.13:2.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.13:2.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn55.13:3.1.pli: Yathārūpena ca kho, āvuso, dhamme appasādena samannāgato assutavā puthujjano kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa dhamme appasādo na hoti.
sn55.13:3.1.eng: They don’t have the distrust in the teaching that causes an unlearned ordinary person to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn55.13:3.2.pli: Yathārūpena ca kho, āvuso, dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgato sutavā ariyasāvako kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa dhamme aveccappasādo hoti—
sn55.13:3.2.eng: And they do have the experiential confidence in the teaching that causes a learned noble disciple to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.13:3.3.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

sn55.13:4.1.pli: Yathārūpena ca kho, āvuso, saṅghe appasādena samannāgato assutavā puthujjano kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa saṅghe appasādo na hoti.
sn55.13:4.1.eng: They don’t have the distrust in the Saṅgha that causes an unlearned ordinary person to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn55.13:4.2.pli: Yathārūpena ca kho, āvuso, saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgato sutavā ariyasāvako kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa saṅghe aveccappasādo hoti—
sn55.13:4.2.eng: And they do have the experiential confidence in the Saṅgha that causes a learned noble disciple to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.13:4.3.pli: suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassāti.
sn55.13:4.3.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, and worthy of veneration with joined palms.’

sn55.13:5.1.pli: Yathārūpena ca kho, āvuso, dussīlyena samannāgato assutavā puthujjano kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati tathārūpassa dussīlyaṃ na hoti.
sn55.13:5.1.eng: They don’t have the unethical conduct that causes an unlearned ordinary person to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn55.13:5.2.pli: Yathārūpehi ca kho, āvuso, ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato sutavā ariyasāvako kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati tathārūpāni ariyakantāni sīlāni honti akhaṇḍāni …pe…
sn55.13:5.2.eng: And they do have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones that causes a learned noble disciple to be reborn—when their body breaks up, after death—in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.13:5.3.eng: Their ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

sn55.13:5.4.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānā imesaṃ catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ samannāgamanahetu evamayaṃ pajā bhagavatā byākatā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti.
sn55.13:5.4.eng: People have to give up these four things and possess these four things in order for the Buddha to declare that they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.14:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sabbaduggatibhayaṃ samatikkanto hoti.
sn55.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things has gone beyond all fear of being reborn in a bad place.

sn55.14:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.14:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.14:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.14:1.7.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.14:1.7.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.14:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sabbaduggatibhayaṃ samatikkanto hotī”ti.
sn55.14:1.8.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things has gone beyond all fear of being reborn in a bad place.”

sn55.15:0.3.eng: Fear of the Bad Place, the Underworld

sn55.15:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things has gone beyond all fear of being reborn in a bad place, the underworld.

sn55.15:1.7.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.15:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sabbaduggativinipātabhayaṃ samatikkanto hotī”ti.
sn55.15:1.8.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things has gone beyond all fear of being reborn in a bad place, the underworld.”

sn55.16:1.1.pli: “Ye te, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ—mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā—te, bhikkhave, catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu samādapetabbā, nivesetabbā, patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
sn55.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the four factors of stream-entry.

sn55.16:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.16:1.7.pli: ariyakantesu sīlesu samādapetabbā, nivesetabbā, patiṭṭhāpetabbā akhaṇḍesu …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikesu.
sn55.16:1.7.eng: And the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.16:1.8.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ—mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā—te, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu samādapetabbā, nivesetabbā, patiṭṭhāpetabbā”ti.
sn55.16:1.8.eng: Those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in these four factors of stream-entry.”

sn55.17:1.1.pli: “Ye te, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ—mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā—te, bhikkhave, catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu samādapetabbā, nivesetabbā, patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
sn55.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the four factors of stream-entry.

sn55.17:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.17:2.1.pli: Siyā, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ aññathattaṃ—pathavīdhātuyā, āpodhātuyā, tejodhātuyā, vāyodhātuyā—na tveva buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa siyā aññathattaṃ.
sn55.17:2.1.eng: There might be change in the four principal states—the elements of earth, water, fire, and air—but a noble disciple with experiential confidence in the Buddha would never change.

sn55.17:2.2.pli: Tatridaṃ aññathattaṃ—so vata buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato ariyasāvako nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjissatī”ti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn55.17:2.2.eng: In this context, ‘change’ means that such a noble disciple will be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm: this is quite impossible.

sn55.17:2.5.pli: ariyakantesu sīlesu samādapetabbā, nivesetabbā, patiṭṭhāpetabbā akhaṇḍesu …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikesu.
sn55.17:2.5.eng: The ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.17:2.6.pli: Siyā, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ aññathattaṃ—pathavīdhātuyā, āpodhātuyā, tejodhātuyā, vāyodhātuyā—na tveva ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa siyā aññathattaṃ.
sn55.17:2.6.eng: There might be change in the four principal states—the elements of earth, water, fire, and air—but a noble disciple with the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones would never change.

sn55.17:2.7.pli: Tatridaṃ aññathattaṃ—so vata ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato ariyasāvako nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn55.17:2.7.eng: In this context, ‘change’ means that such a noble disciple will be reborn in hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm: this is quite impossible.

sn55.17:2.8.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, anukampeyyātha, ye ca sotabbaṃ maññeyyuṃ—mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā—te, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu samādapetabbā, nivesetabbā, patiṭṭhāpetabbā”ti.
sn55.17:2.8.eng: Those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in these four factors of stream-entry.”

sn55.18:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—jetavane antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
sn55.18:1.2.eng: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.

sn55.18:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā tāvatiṃsakāyikā devatāyo yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tā devatāyo āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:
sn55.18:1.3.eng: Then several deities of the company of the thirty-three went up to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, bowed, and stood to one side. Moggallāna said to them:

sn55.18:2.1.pli: “Sādhu kho, āvuso, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanaṃ hoti—
sn55.18:2.1.eng: “Reverends, it’s good to have experiential confidence in the Buddha. …

sn55.18:2.2.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.18:2.3.pli: Buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanahetu kho, āvuso, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
sn55.18:2.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.18:2.4.eng: It’s good to have experiential confidence in the teaching. …

sn55.18:2.6.pli: sādhu kho, āvuso, ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanaṃ hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.18:2.6.eng: and to have the ethical conduct that’s loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.18:2.7.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanahetu kho, āvuso, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
sn55.18:2.7.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

sn55.18:3.1.eng: “My good Moggallāna, it’s good to have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.18:3.2.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.18:3.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.18:3.4.eng: It’s good to have experiential confidence in the teaching. …

sn55.18:3.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanaṃ hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.18:3.6.eng: and to have the ethical conduct that’s loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.18:3.7.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

sn55.2:0.3.eng: The Culmination of the Spiritual Life

sn55.2:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.2:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.2:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti:
sn55.2:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.2:2.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.

sn55.2:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.2:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.2:2.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn55.2:2.7.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.2:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn55.2:3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn55.2:3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn55.2:4.2.eng: confidence, and vision of the truth,

sn55.2:4.4.eng: the culmination of the spiritual life.”

sn55.20:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—jetavane antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
sn55.20:1.1.eng: Then the Buddha, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.

sn55.20:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā tāvatiṃsakāyikā devatāyo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tā devatāyo bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.20:1.2.eng: Then several deities of the company of the thirty-three went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. The Buddha said to them:

sn55.20:2.1.pli: “Sādhu kho, āvuso, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanaṃ hoti—
sn55.20:2.1.eng: “Reverends, it’s good to have experiential confidence in the Buddha. …

sn55.20:2.2.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.20:2.3.pli: Buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanahetu kho, āvuso, evam’idhekacce sattā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
sn55.20:2.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.20:2.4.eng: It’s good to have experiential confidence in the teaching. …

sn55.20:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanaṃ hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.20:2.6.eng: and to have the ethical conduct that’s loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.20:2.7.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanahetu kho, āvuso, evam’idhekacce sattā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti.
sn55.20:2.7.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.20:3.1.pli: “Sādhu kho, mārisa, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanaṃ hoti—
sn55.20:3.1.eng: “Good fellow, it’s good to have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.20:3.2.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.20:3.3.pli: Buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanahetu kho, mārisa, evamayaṃ pajā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
sn55.20:3.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.20:3.4.eng: It’s good to have experiential confidence in the teaching. …

sn55.20:3.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanaṃ hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.20:3.6.eng: and to have the ethical conduct that’s loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.20:3.7.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanahetu kho, mārisa, evamayaṃ pajā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti.
sn55.20:3.7.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.21:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn55.21:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn55.21:1.3.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.21:1.3.eng: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn55.21:1.4.pli: “idaṃ, bhante, kapilavatthu iddhañceva phītañca bāhujaññaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ sambādhabyūhaṃ.
sn55.21:1.4.eng: “Sir, this Kapilavatthu is successful and prosperous, populous, full of people, with cramped cul-de-sacs.

sn55.21:1.5.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ vā payirupāsitvā manobhāvanīye vā bhikkhū sāyanhasamayaṃ kapilavatthuṃ pavisanto;
sn55.21:1.5.eng: In the late afternoon, after paying homage to the Buddha or an esteemed mendicant, I enter Kapilavatthu.

sn55.21:1.11.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, tasmiṃ samaye mussateva bhagavantaṃ ārabbha sati, mussati dhammaṃ ārabbha sati, mussati saṅghaṃ ārabbha sati.
sn55.21:1.11.eng: At that time I lose mindfulness regarding the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.

sn55.21:1.13.pli: ‘imamhi cāhaṃ samaye kālaṃ kareyyaṃ, kā mayhaṃ gati, ko abhisamparāyo’”ti?
sn55.21:1.13.eng: ‘If I were to die at this time, where would I be reborn in my next life?’”

sn55.21:2.1.eng: “Do not fear, Mahānāma, do not fear!

sn55.21:2.2.pli: Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati apāpikā kālaṅkiriyā.
sn55.21:2.2.eng: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.

sn55.21:2.3.pli: Yassa kassaci, mahānāma, dīgharattaṃ saddhāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sīlaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sutaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ cāgaparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ, tassa yo hi khvāyaṃ kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo.
sn55.21:2.3.eng: Take someone whose mind has for a long time been imbued with faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. Their body is formed, made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.

sn55.21:2.4.pli: Taṃ idheva kākā vā khādanti gijjhā vā khādanti kulalā vā khādanti sunakhā vā khādanti siṅgālā vā khādanti vividhā vā pāṇakajātā khādanti;
sn55.21:2.4.eng: Right here the crows, vultures, hawks, hounds, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures devour it.

sn55.21:2.5.pli: yañca khvassa cittaṃ dīgharattaṃ saddhāparibhāvitaṃ …pe… paññāparibhāvitaṃ taṃ uddhagāmi hoti visesagāmi.
sn55.21:2.5.eng: But their mind rises up, headed for a higher place.

sn55.21:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahānāma, puriso sappikumbhaṃ vā telakumbhaṃ vā gambhīraṃ udakarahadaṃ ogāhitvā bhindeyya.
sn55.21:3.1.eng: Suppose a person was to sink a pot of ghee or oil into a deep lake and break it open.

sn55.21:3.2.pli: Tatra yā assa sakkharā vā kaṭhalā vā sā adhogāmī assa, yañca khvassa tatra sappi vā telaṃ vā taṃ uddhagāmi assa visesagāmi.
sn55.21:3.2.eng: Its shards and chips would sink down, while the ghee or oil in it would rise up, headed for a higher place.

sn55.21:3.3.pli: Evameva kho, mahānāma, yassa kassaci dīgharattaṃ saddhāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ …pe…
sn55.21:3.3.eng: In the same way, take someone whose mind has for a long time been imbued with faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. Their body consists of form, made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.

sn55.21:3.4.pli: paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ tassa yo hi khvāyaṃ kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo taṃ idheva kākā vā khādanti gijjhā vā khādanti kulalā vā khādanti sunakhā vā khādanti siṅgālā vā khādanti vividhā vā pāṇakajātā khādanti;
sn55.21:3.4.eng: Right here the crows, vultures, hawks, hounds, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures devour it.

sn55.21:3.5.pli: yañca khvassa cittaṃ dīgharattaṃ saddhāparibhāvitaṃ …pe… paññāparibhāvitaṃ taṃ uddhagāmi hoti visesagāmi.
sn55.21:3.5.eng: But their mind rises up, headed for a higher place.

sn55.21:3.6.pli: Tuyhaṃ kho pana, mahānāma, dīgharattaṃ saddhāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ …pe… paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ.
sn55.21:3.6.eng: Your mind, Mahānāma, has for a long time been imbued with faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

sn55.21:3.7.pli: Mā bhāyi, mahānāma, mā bhāyi, mahānāma.
sn55.21:3.7.eng: Do not fear, Mahānāma, do not fear!

sn55.21:3.8.pli: Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati, apāpikā kālaṅkiriyā”ti.
sn55.21:3.8.eng: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.”

sn55.22:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn55.22:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn55.22:1.3.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.22:1.3.eng: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn55.22:1.4.pli: “idaṃ, bhante, kapilavatthu iddhañceva phītañca bāhujaññaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ sambādhabyūhaṃ.
sn55.22:1.4.eng: “Sir, this Kapilavatthu is successful and prosperous, populous, full of people, with cramped cul-de-sacs.

sn55.22:1.5.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ vā payirupāsitvā manobhāvanīye vā bhikkhū sāyanhasamayaṃ kapilavatthuṃ pavisanto;
sn55.22:1.5.eng: In the late afternoon, after paying homage to the Buddha or an esteemed mendicant, I enter Kapilavatthu.

sn55.22:1.11.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, tasmiṃ samaye mussateva bhagavantaṃ ārabbha sati, mussati dhammaṃ ārabbha sati, mussati saṅghaṃ ārabbha sati.
sn55.22:1.11.eng: At that time I lose mindfulness regarding the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.

sn55.22:1.13.pli: ‘imamhi cāhaṃ samaye kālaṃ kareyyaṃ, kā mayhaṃ gati, ko abhisamparāyo’”ti?
sn55.22:1.13.eng: ‘If I were to die at this time, where would I be reborn in my next life?’”

sn55.22:2.1.eng: “Do not fear, Mahānāma, do not fear!

sn55.22:2.2.pli: Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati apāpikā kālaṅkiriyā.
sn55.22:2.2.eng: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.

sn55.22:2.3.pli: Catūhi kho, mahānāma, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn55.22:2.3.eng: A noble disciple who has four things slants, slopes, and inclines towards extinguishment.

sn55.22:2.5.pli: Idha, mahānāma, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.22:2.5.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.22:2.6.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.22:2.9.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.22:2.9.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.22:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahānāma, rukkho pācīnaninno pācīnapoṇo pācīnapabbhāro, so mūlacchinno katamena papateyyā”ti?
sn55.22:3.1.eng: Suppose there was a tree that slants, slopes, and inclines to the east. If it was cut off at the root where would it fall?”

sn55.22:3.2.pli: “Yena, bhante, ninno yena poṇo yena pabbhāro”ti.
sn55.22:3.2.eng: “Sir, it would fall in the direction that it slants, slopes, and inclines.”

sn55.22:3.3.pli: “Evameva kho, mahānāma, imehi catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn55.22:3.3.eng: “In the same way, a noble disciple who has four things slants, slopes, and inclines towards extinguishment.”
